Wild Rose Risk Management Plan
Executive Summary

Accidental Release Prevention and Emergency Response Policies

It is Ormat Nevada, Inc.'s (Ormat's) policy to adhere to all applicable federal, state, and local laws. The Wild Rose facility actively manages all operational permits and safety programs such as Nevada Division of Environmental Protection's Air Quality, Chemical Accident Prevention Program, Underground Injection Control programs as well as OSHA's Process Safety Management program. In addition, Ormat is ISO 14000 and 9001 certified and undergoes several audit processes to ensure all facilities are aggressively pursuing the highest quality, safety and environmental standards. Ormat is committed to handling the n-butane systems in a safe manner to protect the environment. Copies of emergency response, process hazard analyses, Chemical Accident Prevention and process safety management plans and all technical drawings (P&IDS) for process equipment are maintained onsite for reference.

Facility Description
The Wild Rose Geothermal Power Plant (Wild Rose) is wholly owned by ORNI 47, LLC (Ormat), which is a division of Ormat Technologies, Inc., a publicly traded company. The Wild Rose Project is located in Mineral County.  The well pads, pipelines and plant encompass approximately 55 acres of public lands.  Additionally, the power transmission line extends 20.5 miles.  The physical plant is located on approximately 10 acres and is located 22 miles west of Gabbs, Nevada on Rawhide Road. The leased acreage covers the defined geothermal resource area and receptive injection zones.

The physical address is: 	Wild Rose Geothermal Power Plant
1132 Gabbs Valley Road
Luning, NV 89420

The Wild Rose Plant is a geothermal electric power generation facility with one, Integrated Two Level Unit (ITLU) air-cooled Ormat Energy Converter (OEC).  The OEC incorporates one double-ended shaft generator driven by two, 1800 RPM direct coupled special organic fluid turbi

nes, and associated facilities. Geothermal fluid is supplied from five production wells.  Spent geothermal fluid is injected back into the subsurface reservoir via three injection wells.

Wild Rose is operated by Ormat's Eastern Nevada Operations Group (ENOP). ENOP is comprised of management, administration, maintenance, engineering and operations personnel.  They operate three eastern Nevada power generation facilities owned by Ormat in addition to Wild Rose.

The Wild Rose facility operates continuously, 24 hours per day and 365 days per year (excluding scheduled maintenance downtime or plant upsets).  During the initial startup phase, the plant is staffed full time, but will eventually be operated remotely from the McGinness Hills Geothermal Power Plant Control Room, which is central to all ENOP-operated facilities.  During remote operation, two full time employees will be dedicated to provide routine field monitoring and preventative maintenance.  12 additional part time employees will provide the equivalent of four more full time employees to bring the total number of full time employees to six.

Regulated Substance Handled
Wild Rose utilizes n-butane (CAS # 106-97-8) as the motive fluid in the OEC unit. In addition to the inventory present in the OEC, the plant has three n-butane storage tanks.  Each tank has a nominal capacity of 36,000 gallons each (maximum fill capacity of 32,400 gallons).  The maximum total projected amount of n-butane to be stored on site is 530,878 pounds (reflects the inventory in the operational OEC and one storage tank containing two, full truck-loads of n-butane which is approximately 18,000 gallons). The use of n-butane in a process in a quantity greater than 10,000 lbs requires compliance with PSM (29CFR1910.119), RMP (40CFR68) and CAPP (Nevada Administrative Code 459.952 to 459.95528).  The n-butane is projected to first be stored on the site in November, 2013.

Worst Case Scenario: Worst case scenario assessment has been

made and potential off-site consequence
analysis (OCA) was undertaken. However, in conformance with Office of Emergency Management guidance, the OCA for worst-case and/or alternative release scenario(s) has not been included in this Executive Summary because of security concerns.

Safe Work Practices: Safe work practices have been developed and implemented to provide for the control of hazards during work activities such as lock out/tag-out, confined space entry, opening process equipment or piping, and control over entrance into a facility by maintenance, contractor, laboratory or other support personnel. These safe work practices apply to both employees and contractors.

Maintenance Procedures: A Mechanical Integrity Program (MIP) has been initiated at the Wild Rose
facility. The MIP adopted a maintenance concept for periodic preventative and corrective maintenance of the OEC system at Wild Rose. The preventative maintenance tasks include visual inspection, lubrication of rotating parts, system cleaning, replacing liquids and filters, and periodic tests to verify that the system is in proper operating condition. Preventative maintenance tasks and procedures are scheduled to be undertaken over a series of maintenance intervals.

Alarm system maintenance is determined using a combination of regulatory requirements, manufacturer's recommendations, plant operating experience and best practices. The Standard Maintenance Procedures (SMP's) will identify system maintenance procedures, frequencies and recommended spare parts.

Training: Initial training for personnel is given before that employee is allowed to either handle n-butane,
operate or work in the facility's process area or on process equipment. Initial training shall be completed
with Emergency Services Personnel including a tour of the site, gas and fire detection system operations, and familiarization with the motive fluid characteristics.

Refresher training is conducted on an annual basis, at

a minimum, and when review of the chemicals or
process reveals a need for additional training. Initial and refresher training, associated with the Risk Management Program, is documented and maintained per the requirements of the Training Program.  Additional training will also be provided as needed or requested by Emergency Services Personnel. Contracted employees, shall be trained in the requirements of the EAP procedure prior to working at the Wild Rose site. Training will include the following items, but is not limited to: (a) Location and sounds of the stand down, and evacuation alarms; (b) Expectations of response to injuries and emergencies by personnel on site; and (c) Evacuation routes and locations. Refresher training for all personnel shall be conducted annually at a minimum.

Safety Training: Some equipment at the Wild Rose Geothermal Power Plant poses potential fire, explosion, and electrical hazards that could cause serious personal injuries and costly property damage if safety procedures are not followed correctly. Safety training, conducted monthly and required of all employees, identifies the different hazards to be found on the sites. These subjects include Emergency Action Plan (EAP), motive fluid hazards, fire prevention and hot work, lock out and tag out procedures, hazard communication, confined space, hearing conservation, personal protective equipment, accident, injury and incident reporting. Safety training is supplemented by the use of the Standard Safety Procedures.

n-butane system: Deviation from the design limits of operation for the n-butane transfer system will not normally occur since the individual components are rated beyond the highest achievable values of pressure, temperature, and flow within the system.

OEC Unit: The OEC unit is controlled and monitored by its own dedicated Programmable Logic
Controller (PLC). The PLC receives all discrete (logic) and analog signals from the input devices (e.g. switches and measuring se

nsors), processes the signals according to pre-loaded Ormat software, and then outputs logic and analog command signals to local and field devices. All parameters needed for proper operation of the OEC units, such as pressure, temperature, voltage, current, power, speed, etc. are measured by the proper measuring instruments. Deviation from the operating parameters will immediately be detected by the PLC and the PLC will initiate correction or automatic shutdown of the related OEC unit. Under normal circumstances, no releases or other dangerous situations are expected to result from these automatic actions. Appropriate manual override is provided.

Relief system design: Relief valves are located on the n-butane storage tanks and on the OEC vaporizers and condensers. Each pressure relief valve relieves directly to atmosphere. Additionally, each pressure relief valve is installed immediately above a rupture disk designed to fail at the relief pressure of its corresponding relief valve. Individual relief valve locations are equipped with "telltale" gauges in between the relief valve and its rupture disk to allow easy identification of leaking or blown rupture disks. The following list summarizes the system relief set points:

  n-butane Storage Tank Relief: 120 psig
  Condenser: 120 psig
  Vaporizer: 400 psig

Ventilation System Design: All components of the n-butane transfer and storage systems and the OEC units are located outdoors.

Safety Systems: Beyond the relief system the Wild Rose, the OEC unit has extensive fire protection, gas and flame detection, and alarm systems.  These protective systems, in conjunction with the administrative control system, ensure the focus is upon fire prevention.

The fire detection systems include gas monitors which continuously monitor the area surrounding the OEC, and ultraviolet/infrared flame detectors throughout the plant. The facility has a fire water system installed in a continuous loop around the generating units

and within reach of the n-butane storage tanks and major process equipment. The fire water systems consist of fire monitors and hydrants, and a diesel driven fire pump that draws from a 200,000 gallon fire water tank (nominal capacity). Operators are trained in the proper use of the installed fire protection equipment, and the training information is appropriately documented by the facility operator.

Process Hazard Analysis
A Process Hazardous Analysis (PHA) including Hazard and Operability (HAZOP) study, an external events
analysis, and a preliminary human factors analysis was undertaken in September, 2012 and was  revised several times through September, 2013. The recommendations of the PHA were integrated into the facility and facility operations. The PHA will be updated and revalidated at least every 5 years to ensure the study is consistent for the life of the butane processes.

Five-Year Accident History
The Wild Rose power plant is a new facility and there have been no accidents associated with butane and no accidental releases of butane.

Emergency Response Program
The Emergency Response Program is intended to identify and coordinate personnel in the event there is an emergency. The EAP procedures apply to all personnel working at the Wild Rose facility or monitoring the Wild Rose plant from the McGinness Hills monitoring facility. The EAP is submitted to the local fire department and LEPC for review and their concurrence when changes are made to the plan. Annual meetings are scheduled to coordinate potential response activities by Ormat personnel and the local fire department. 

Implementation, Control and Compliance: The Plant Manager has overall responsibility for the development and implementation of the Emergency Action Plan. The Emergency Action Plan is reviewed annually to verify regulatory compliance and accuracy with both OSHA Regulations on Emergency Plans 29CFR1910.38 and CAPP's Emergency Response Programs, NAC 459.9544. The Emergenc

y Response Program is also periodically reviewed and updated and employees notified of any changes in conformance with 40 CFR 68.95. The EAP may also be reviewed, as part of any Incident Investigations or when deemed required during Management of Change. Current copies of the Emergency Action Plan will be located in the Wild Rose Control Building and in the McGinness Hills Control Room.

Evacuation of Personnel: In the event of an emergency determined to be butane system-related and
evacuation is deemed necessary, the control room operator or other designated personnel will sound the
plant evacuation alarm.

First Aid: All personnel have been trained in adult CPR and basic first aid procedures.

Control Room Operator: Upon notification from the site that an emergency has occurred, the Control Room Operator verifies that appropriate response activities have been initiated and emergency response teams have been called. The Control Room Operator assumes initial communications with site personnel during emergency situations until relieved by either the Plant Manager or Operations Manager.

Emergency Response Personnel: Fire, police, and/or ambulance crews will be called if necessary. The senior employee on site at the time of the incident will give a report to the person in charge of the emergency teams.  The emergency responders assume the role of Incident Commander upon arrival.

Planned Changes To Improve Safety
Because Wild Rose is a new facility, it has no record of any emergency action or incidents and there are currently no planned changes to improve safety beyond what was already identified and resolved in the most recent PHA revision.
